Award.AwardTitle: Planning Grant: I/UCRC for Next Generation CAx joining the Center for e-Design
Award.AbstractNarration:
0968876 Brigham Young University (BYU); Gregory Jensen
0968957 University of Puerto Rico (UPR); David Serrano

Brigham Young University (BYU) and the University of Puerto Rico (UPR) propose to join the existing Center for e-Design that is currently comprised of Virginia Tech (lead), the University of Central Florida and the University of Massachusetts.

YU and UPR will complement the research umbrella by investigating, modifying, and prototyping, at kernel levels, new architectures for networked multi-user computer-aided applications (v-CAx). The new institutions will add strategically to Center goals, because of their strong histories in applications of modern CAx software. The proposed research will support the existing Center?s infrastructure research in all four thrust areas, but will strongly complement Thrust II: New Paradigms and Processes. The intellectual merit will be measured by how the rather subtle perturbations to the computer operating systems (OS) and CAx architectures collapse product development times for multi-users.

The new universities bring cultural diversity to the research that will be demanded by research prototypes. BYU will extend and integrate CAx applications through API libraries, computer OS architectures, network security, and business team conflict resolution. While BYU has strong relationships with several international institutions that have expertise in gaming technologies, UPR has backgrounds in constraint relationships as they relate to design parameters. BYU's and UPR's strong dependence on both undergraduate and graduate students for development and testing, will provide students a rich educational experience. The universities also plan to involve K-12 and post K-12 levels in the Center.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A planning grant was submitted to the NSF I/UCRC Program in order to create a site of the Center for e-Design at the University of Puerto Rico Mayaguez (UPRM). The proposed UPRM contribution to the ongoing Center for e-Design was the addition of next generation multi-user collaborative computer aided engineering tools. To this effect UPRM teamed with BYU, as new institutions, to bring e-Design collaborative research breadth critical to the next generation multi-user CAx research objectives, falling well within established research boundaries established for the NSF Center for e-Design. In addition, the proposed UPRM site seeks to contribute to the integration of ethnically diverse groups of departments and students and complements the NSF I/UCRC Center for e-Design.

 

A major effort by the PI, Dr. David Serrano and the co-PI, Dr. Stefano Leonardi, included the identification of prospective industry and government members for the UPRM site, meetings and presentations to identify industry needs that lead to collaborative research projects within the scope of the I/UCRC Center for e-Design and the next generation multi-user collaboration tools. The US aerospace industry, a growing segment of the local (Puerto Rico) economy, was selected as the primary target to support at the UPRM site. The primary needs of the target industry include collaboration among remote sites, advanced CAE tools and human resource development in these areas. As a result of these efforts two main research projects were identified and included in the joint BYU-UPRM meeting held August 11-13, 2010. the included projects were: (1) Multi-User Constraint Negotiation for Collaborative CAx and (2) Multi-physics, Multi-user Environment for Aerospace Industry.

The successful meeting was held concurrently with the participation of two sites (BYU and UPRM, with a two time zone difference) and virtual participation over WebEx for attendees not present at either site. The meeting itself was a demonstration of the collaborative focus of the multi-user CAx focus proposed by BYU and UPRM. A total of 8 projects were presented at the meeting 6 by BYU and 2 by UPRM. Total of ten UPRM attendees, nine present at the UPRM site one at BYU site. A total of five industrial members were represented at the UPRM site; GearBox Software, Honeywell International, Infotech Aerospace, FTT, Raytheon and two government agencies: PRIDCO and Vitec2.  A major commitment from the Puerto Rico Industrial Development Company (PRIDCO, a state government agency) was obtained as a result of the meeting. A subsequent proposal to PRIDCO's Aerospace Challenge program secured a 1 to 1 matching for funding from industry members joining the proposed UPRM site and for NSF funding up to a total of $375,000 in 3 years, with an option for renewal thereafter. As a result of the effort a proposal to join the Center for e-Design was submitted to the NSF I/UCRC Program.

The proposed tools directly impact areas in Engineering (Mechanical, Aerospace, Automotive, Electrical, Industrial Engineering) as well as Computer Science (Visualization, User Interaction, Model Representation and Computational Paradigms, Human Factors) and Engineering Education. The successful deployment of the identified tools should have a significant impact on the competitiveness of US industry, allowing shorter product development cycles and lower development costs.

 

The images were taken during the planning meeting held at Mayaguez, PR, USA on August 11-13, 2010.
